0805079831|3.0|`Disaster Capitalism', which with its soul-mate, hegemonic neoliberalism, feeds, like the real-life piranhas and parasitic 'gangster oligarchs' it spawns, from Johannesburg to Beijing via Moscow and Buenos Aires, off the human carcasses and physical wreckage of wars (Iraq and Afghanistan), tsunamis (Sri Lanka and Thailand), tornadoes (New Orleans/Gulf region, Caribbean/Mexico ) and similar eco-economic devastation, but it's a story that has not been fully synthesized before.<br /><br />This seems to be the major message of Naomi Klein's new book: \\"The Shock Doctrine - The Rise of Disaster Capitalism\\" [Metropolitan Books, NY, 2007]. Like her previously well received books, it will be a best seller, despite its size, 466 pages [alt. 533 pages].<br /><br />Transposing the metaphor from the world of the 50s `experimental psychiatry' [lobotomy, electro-shock treatment (ECT) to psychedelic drugs] to the real world of today's casino economics.  It is in revealing the inter-connectedness of the 'shocked'n'singed'  electrodes or nerve-centres to the Brains Trust that rules and directs this vicious system, that is Klein's greatest achievement.<br /><br />Economics, that infamous `dismal science' stands revealed in its latest apparition, as `voodoo economics' - enter Chief Witchdoctor, (the late) Milton Friedman, as chief villain in the piece, a modern Dr Strangelove of the academ&eacute; and his prescribed economic \\"shock treatment\\" doctrine. Where Klein could presumably claim originality is in identifying the taxonomy of this \\"shock doctrine\\", the latest in capitalism's phases of \\"creative destruction\\" [with its reference to `manic-depressive disorders'], as Schumpeter described the core of the system in the 1950s.<br /><br />So she describes the 'systemic shock' of a sudden overpowering attack, whether the overthrow of Salvador Allende in Chile in 1973, or the bombing of Baghdad in 2003; the shock of torturers using sensory deprivation techniques and crude electrodes to instil fear and acquiescence. The methods used in Guant&aacute;namo Bay or Abu Ghirab. The economics of 'disaster capitalism' and contemporary global reality.<br /><br />Methodically combined and skilfully elaborated, these onslaughts now amount, on Klein's account, to a supposedly new and frightful chapter in the history of ghoulish capitalist predation. Maybe her core argument is a-historical, as globalizing capitalist penetration of `non-capitalist' environments is over 500 years old and its attendant social-psychic `culture shocks' on indigenous populations have already been recorded. It's as if Rosa Luxemburg, V.I. Lenin or Karl Polyani had never existed.<br /><br />In fact \\"shock therapy\\" neoliberalism really isn't most closely associated with Friedman at all, but rather with Jeffrey Sachs, note an ex-Harvard lecturer not a `Chicago Boy', to whom Klein devotes much space, even though Friedman remains the sinister dark emminence of her story. A straw man really, easily demolished and easily forgotten.<br /><br />Sachs first introduced shock therapy in Bolivia in the early 1990s. Then he went into Poland, Russia etc, with the same shock therapy model. Sachs' catchy phrase was that \\"you can't leap over an abyss step-by-step\\". This is really where contemporary neoliberalism emerged and morphed, like the Creature of the Black Lagoon, to terrorize the globe.<br /><br />Just as there has been continuity in capitalist predation, there is continuity, albeit uneven, in resistance. Here's where Klein's implicit catastrophism may distort the real picture - her controlling metaphor for the attack on Iraq, is the initial \\"shock and awe\\" bombardment, designed to numb Saddam's forces and the civilian population into instant surrender, long-term submission and re-colonization. But \\"shock and awe\\" was a myth - it spawned resistance to present-day `reconstruction' efforts, not defeat and apathy.<br /><br />The last chapters of her book point to this increasing resistance in many places around the globe, not least in Iraq, with its outsourced just-in-time mercenary genocide &aacute;-la Blackwater or Halliburton and Bechtel's corporate looting, and Latin America's Southern Cone, the site of the first modern neoliberal onslaught, over forty years ago.<br /><br />One is left with the numbing feeling of \\"something's missing\\". The body of evidence of neoliberalism destruction, not creation, is overwhelming - but from the anti-capitalist point of view she's far too pessimistic. A capitalism that thrives best on the `abnormal', on disasters, is by definition in decline [thus 'terminally sick', `in its death-throes'].<br /><br />In sum, Naomi Klein has done a sterling job to collate, record and reveal the workings of contemporary `Disaster Capitalism', and like fellow prize-winning investigative journalist John Pilger and writer Arundhati Roy, has exposed the nature and workings of the system today called neoliberalism. Whatever her theoretical `deficiencies' and `inconsistencies' (and there might be many), her work is in the admirable muckraking North American tradition of I.F. Stone, Upton Sinclair, John Steinbeck, or a contemporary like Mike Davis and the late Norman Mailer.<br /><br />Read Naomi Klein's work and discuss it, and despite my minor reservations, for example her chapter on South Africa is schematic and not convincing really, I fully endorse this important work as \\"essential reading\\". But the dark scenarios presented in chapter after grim chapter, backed by its well-researched evidence (thanks to her expert teams) leave one flat, as in `shock'.<br /><br />What happens when the `shock' wears off? \\"The point is to change it (the world)\\" is still as relevant as ever, but which social and political forces, tools or instruments, are there at hand? Put in another way, does Hugo Chavez and Evo Morales in Latin America show the way forward?<br /><br />Only time will tell...<br /><br />Selim Gool, November 14, 2007.<br />selimgool@yahoo.comrcenary genocide -la Blackwater or Halliburton and Bechtel's corporate looting, and Latin America's Southern Cone, the site of the first modern neoliberal onslaught, over forty years ago.     One is left with the numbing feeling of \\"something's missing\\". The body of evidence of neoliberalism destruction, not creation, is overwhelming - but from the anti-capitalist point of view she's far too pessimistic. A capitalism that thrives best on the `abnormal', on disasters, is by definition in decline [thus 'terminally sick', `in its death-throes'].     In sum, Naomi Klein has done a sterling job to collate, record and reveal the workings of contemporary `Disaster Capitalism', and like fellow prize-winning investigative journalist John Pilger and writer Arundhati Roy, has exposed the nature and workings of the system today called neoliberalism. Whatever her theoretical `deficiencies' and `inconsistencies' (and there might be many), her work is in the admirable muckraking North American tradition of I.F. Stone, Upton Sinclair, John Steinbeck, or a contemporary like Mike Davis and the late Norman Mailer.     Read Naomi Klein's work and discuss it, and despite my minor reservations, for example her chapter on South Africa is schematic and not convincing really, I fully endorse this important work as \\"essential reading\\". But the dark scenarios presented in chapter after grim chapter, backed by its well-researched evidence (thanks to her expert teams) leave one flat, as in `shock'.     What happens when the `shock' wears off? \\"The point is to change it (the world)\\" is still as relevant as ever, but which social and political forces, tools or instruments, are there at hand? Put in another way, does Hugo Chavez and Evo Morales in Latin America show the way forward?     Only time will tell...           Selim Gool, November 14, 2007.   selimgool@yahoo.com

B00003CXC7|5.0|Rear window was taken from a short story entitled, \\"It had to be Murder\\" by Cornell Woolrich and adapted to the screen by John Michael Hayes  ([[ASIN:B000CCW2TS The Man Who Knew Too Much]]) & ([[ASIN:B000MX7V5M To Catch a Thief (Special Collector's Edition)]]). To Catch a Thief was Hayes's second collaboration with Hitchcock after Rear Window.<br /><br />What makes this particular thriller one of the all time greats in cinematic history is its simplicity, revealing human nature's tendency to voyeurism.<br /><br />L. B. Jefferies (Jimmy Stewart) is a photo journalist, forced to sit in his apartment because of a broken leg. He becomes extremely bored because his only contact to the outside world is his editor by phone, his nurse played with humour and charm, Stella (Thelma Ritter) and his stunning, rich girlfriend, Lisa Carole Fremont, (Grace Kelly) To alleviate his boredom, through the lens of his telescopic camera, he is able to spy on all his neighbours through his back window. It is through Jeffries eyes that the story is told as we get to know so many different characters with their interesting, mundane, sometimes lonely and murderous lives.<br /><br />Jefferies girlfriend, Lisa, visits him frequently, and in one scene brings in a catered dinner of lobster and fine champagne, looking absolutely ravishing to get Jefferies to stop obsessing with his telescope and his spying. Despite her beauty and the brilliant food, Jefferies has a suspicion: one of his neighbours has killed his wife, chopped up her body, and disposes the evidence in several trips with a suitcase. This fixation turns obsessive and suddenly manic as the evidence mounts against the \\"husband\\" (Raymond Burr).<br /><br />There are two story-telling devices that make a great thriller, mounting tension and the element of surprise. Rear Window has these qualities and much more.<br /><br />For me the best aspect of this film is the stories within the main story. Through the eyes of Jefferies we become intimate with his neighbours and their various situations, some interesting, some plain evil, some mostly sad and terribly lonely. It's like the old adage: if you feel your life is a drag, look at other lives and miraculously, your problems are not that serious or sad.<br /><br />I remember watching this film as a child and almost climbing the walls in fear at the end. Viewing the film so many years later, I didn't climb the walls but felt the same tension.<br /><br />Rear Window has to be one of the great thrillers in the history of film.r various situations, some interesting, some plain evil, some mostly sad and terribly lonely. It's like the old adage: if you feel your life is a drag, look at other lives and miraculously, your problems are not that serious or sad.    I remember watching this film as a child and almost climbing the walls in fear at the end. Viewing the film so many years later, I didn't climb the walls but felt the same tension.     Rear Window has to be one of the great thrillers in the history of film.

0891419195|5.0|This book delivers exactly what the reviewers say:  it's not a grand overview of the war.  It's only what one soldier saw through his eyes in two vicious campaigns.  A young idealistic soldier heads to combat and 6 months later he is attempting to salvage gold teeth from a Japanese corpse before he comes to his senses.  But plenty of other's don't.  The brutality of war is vividly brought home here:  the atrocities on both sides, the fear of constant bombardment by heavy guns, the friendly fire killings as well as one accidental discharge killing a best friend in the company.  The survival rates here are so low it's amazing more soldiers didn't lose their minds.  What this book covered that I have never seen before is the horrible conditions in the battlefield which he provides such as the stench of rotting dead bodies for days.  In addition to describing this so well he also adds details of basic human bodily waste while tied to a foxhole which you must now live in for days in the rain and mud of Okinawa or the heat and coral of Pelilui allowing no ability to bury this waste.  Covered for the first time are descriptions of moving equipment and supplies to the front line as well as the deadly stretcher duty of wounded soldiers with bullets flying.  Maybe the most terrifying story is an open field crossing with Japanese machine guns at the end setting up a killing zone allowing about a 50% survival rate but with no other choice.<br /><br />In summary this is just a powerful story that needs to be read.  It's neither sexy nor filled with Patriotic fervor.  It's about soldiers in the worst possible conditions and the 20 feet in front of them that will determine whether they survive.  And it's absolutely a chilling, must read.

B000007XUQ|5.0|As a 40-something whose tastes have matured with the years, the appreciation for the genuine genius of Richard and Karen Carpenter has increased exponentially.  I am old enough to remember hearing them on the radio as a kid, and while they didn't hit my radar until much later in life, it has been with decided relish that I've explored their work.<br /><br />The Christmas Collection, as has been pointed out, is a compilation release of two earlier albums: Christmas Portrait and An Old Fashioned Christmas.  The earlier work (in this set, it is Disc 1) is the definitive Carpenter's Christmas.  Richard's arrangements can only be described as lush, and the more one listens to these phenomenal orchestrations, the more one is awestruck by this gifted talent.  And of course, Karen's vocals are flawless and spot-on, with unfeigned pathos in many of the more somber renditions.<br /><br />The style of this collection runs the gamut from the whimsical to the endearing.  Her voice soars with haunting clarity on tunes like Christ is Born and the venerable Ave Maria.  And no \\"modern traditional\\" Christmas is complete without their holiday signature song, Merry Christmas Darling.  Sleigh Ride, Jingle Bells and other traditional secular tunes are fun and bouncy without becoming childish.<br /><br />The second disc in this collection, originally An Old Fashioned Christmas, is an organic continuation of the first disc, and played back-to-back, they form a seamless whole of enjoyable Christmas fare. The harmonies are rich without appearing over-produced.  They even included one of the few New Year's tunes anyone can think of besides Auld Lang Syne (Frank Loesser's What Are You Doing New Year's Eve?)<br /><br />You don't have to be a Carpenter's fan to enjoy this offering. Chances are, once you listen to it a few times, you'll become one anyway. After nearly three decades since the first album was released, this special holiday gift has aged extremely gracefully, and I can no longer imagine a Christmas without it as a backdrop to the season.backdrop to the season.
0802714544|5.0|John Le Carre's spy novels have thrilled readers for decades, and \\"The Spy Who Came In From the Cold\\" is the novel that kick-started his writing career.  A surprisingly short novel, \\"Spy\\" packs in more high-quality twists and turns than most books twice its length.    Alec Leamus, Le Carre's protagonist, is a bitter British agent stationed in Cold War Berlin.  The Wall has gone up, which both divides the city and makes it a perfect hot-bed for agents of the communist and capitalist powers.  At the outset, the communists have the upper hand - they have killed all of Leamus's agents.  Leamus returns to England in disgrace and, worse, useless.    Or so one would think.  But Control, Leamus's boss, sends Leamus back out for one last mission - to bring down Mundt, the communist agent who destroyed Leamus's network.      What makes Le Carre's novels so special is how they unfold gradually.  This is not James Bond, where M conveniently briefs Bond at the beginning and clearly sets forth who the villain is and what his ambitions are.  Much of the action that occurs in \\"Spy\\" occurs for reasons that are only explained later.  As a result, Le Carre compels the reader to dig deeper into book, searching for clues and hints, only to have Le Carre reveal purposes and motives at the perfectly appropriate time.    Be warned - \\"Spy\\" is a bitter, cynical book.  Leamus has been around the block more than a few times, and he knows he is expendable. But even he is shocked and unnerved at the espionage game's ability to chew up and spit out individuals in pursuit of its own ends.  Readers seeking happy endings and tidy resolutions will be disappointed, but readers seeking a brilliant, unsettling, shocking spy tale will be thrilled.

0060899220|5.0|Anyone who has worked in a professional kitchen, from slop-house to steak house, will find something to love about this book. Written from the point of view of a real restaurant chef, not some phony who prances around on the Food Network. This book tells the true story of life in the trenches, the grueling, unappreciated job of pumping out dish after dish, night after night while suffering the effects of extreme heat, personal injury and indignities at the hands of coworkers and and uncaring public (\\"The cook lost a finger? Who cares?! Where's my steak!\\").   Some of the French terms used in this book may be hard to navigate for those who aren't familiar with fine dining, but they won't take away from the enjoyment of a tale that finally tells the real story of life on the line.   Anyone who buys in to the celebrity chef culture, and believes that a career in the culinary arts will ensure them a dignified and prosperous life needs to read this book first. You have no idea what you're getting yourself into!

0596527055|5.0|Anyone interested in how and why some innovations succeed (no matter what kind) and some fail (no matter what quality) should read Scott Berkun's THE MYTHS OF INNOVATION.  There are 10 myths associated with innovations in the modern world, and they are all illusions.<br /><br />I will briefly discuss two of these myths:<br /><br />\\"The best ideas win.\\"  This is actually a moral vision, NOT an accurate description.  People who say this (or even those who behave as if it were true) are telling others what they think \\"should\\" happen, not what actually does happen.  Execution (putting the idea into practice) depends on many more characteristics than the content or quality of the idea - such things as support from others, access to resources, technological wherewithal, absence of roadblocks, etc.  All of these other things influence the success of ideas (or lack of success) far more than the idea itself.<br /><br />\\"Innovation is always good.\\"  This is actually wishful thinking, not an accurate description.  If it is possible to use an innovation in malevolent or destructive ways, that will usually happen - the only way to prevent this is to design \\"affordances\\" into an innovation that would make it impossible to use except in designated ways.  This is actually impossible, despite certain claims to the contrary - the cost would be prohibitive, AND people's bloody-minded ingenuity can usually overcome whatever product constraints are put in place.  Effective social control requires conditioning as well as affordances, and people will always find ways to \\"think outside the boxes\\" that are designed to constrain their behaviour.  The capacity to regulate depends upon peoples' willingness to be regulated.<br /><br />Do you know, or know of any individual or group that has \\"beat their heads against the wall\\" of these constraints on innovation?  Let me make a few suggestions for where to look for them:  any person or group proposing individual or institutional re-construction will, by their very nature, have an \\"idealized\\" version of \\"what should be\\" that they would like to see replace \\"what is.\\"  It doesn't matter whether that vision of a better future is based on philosophy, psychology, sociology, or technology - all of these types of proposals extrapolate from \\"what is\\" to \\"what might be.\\"  Yet in reality we do not live in a perfect world - nor can we improve or revolutionize the existing world so that it does achieve (or even approach) perfection.  The best ideas don't necessariy prevail - just look around you.  Innovation is not always good - just look around you.<br /><br />There are 8 other myths of innovation, all of them just as incorrect and dangerous as those above - do yourself a favour - read the book, AND use the valuable life-lessons therein to reformulate your attitude about innovations and their role in life - readers should have better things to do with their heads than beating them against walls!an \\"idealized\\" version of \\"what should be\\" that they would like to see replace \\"what is.\\"  It doesn't matter whether that vision of a better future is based on philosophy, psychology, sociology, or technology - all of these types of proposals extrapolate from \\"what is\\" to \\"what might be.\\"  Yet in reality we do not live in a perfect world - nor can we improve or revolutionize the existing world so that it does achieve (or even approach) perfection.  The best ideas don't necessariy prevail - just look around you.  Innovation is not always good - just look around you.    There are 8 other myths of innovation, all of them just as incorrect and dangerous as those above - do yourself a favour - read the book, AND use the valuable life-lessons therein to reformulate your attitude about innovations and their role in life - readers should have better things to do with their heads than beating them against walls!

B000050X31|4.0|As a huge classical music and Mozart fan, I'm giving this one four stars. It's really hard to get a \\"perfect\\" production with a \\"dream team\\" of the very best singers performing at their peak. Add to that that this is a live recording, and I'd say this is a hard-to-beat recording of Mozart's divine singspiel.
